snippet: Forming a wall of players in front of the goal remains a common but imperfect way to defend free kicks, as the United States learned in its World Cup qualifier loss to Jamaica.
abstract: Wall formation traditionally used by soccer teams when an opposing player gets a free kick near the goal is not a foolproof defense, but after experimenting with variations, teams have found that it is usually the best option.
lead_paragraph: Forming a wall of players in front of the goal remains a common but imperfect way to defend free kicks, as the United States learned in its World Cup qualifier loss to Jamaica.
